results.title: A Class of your own
results.creator_credit: Richard Need, John R.F. Stewart and Stewart Films
results.brief_description: Primarily designed for the instruction of the services, this film puts forward principles that are equally applicable to teaching in the civilian field. The instructor must plan his lessons in advance, whether in the classroom or at the workbench. The lesson should have a proper introduction, be developed logically, and flow naturally and interestingly to its concluding summary. The value of class activity, teaching aids, planned questions and proper note-taking are all dealt with in this film. The film falls into two parts: classroom instruction and practical instruction.

results.title: A child grows: the first year
results.brief_description: This program focuses on the physiological and psychological landmarks of the first year of life: noting that the order, not the timing is predictable. Using footage of infants to illustrate each point of maturation, areas covered include; motor development; muscle control and strength - from birth; reflex actions - smiling, rolling over, sitting, crawling, walking; hand-eye co-ordination; exploration of world and link to feeding and digestion; sensory development; language and speech development; developmental norms; attachment, separation and anxiety; development of thinking, planning, goal directed actions and; symbolic representations. Informative and useful to both students and parents of newborns.

results.title: A Child's voice
results.creator_credit: Kieran Hickey, Roland Hill and B.A.C. Films Ltd (Ireland)
results.brief_description: A tale of suspense. Three nights a week, Ainsley Rupert Macreadie writes and broadcasts chilling and intriguing tales of horror to rapt audiences. But his latest cruel narrative becomes a reality when the character of the boy involved refuses to obey the writer’s commands, and Macreadie discovers that he is the victim of the kind of terror which until now he has reserved for others. Starring T.P. McKenna as Ainsley Rupert Macreadie, June Tobin as the child. Written by David Thomson and narrated by Valentine Dyall. (Awards: First Prize Short Fiction Category - Chicago International Film Festival, 1978; Festival Choice - London Film Festival, 1978) Suitable for middle and upper secondary level.

results.title: A Building survives: Olderfleet
results.brief_description: Features an interview with the architects and/or builders who renovated the Olderfleet building in Collins Street, Melbourne without destroying its original facade. From the ABC television program “This Day Tonight” October 1973.

results.title: A Brother for Susan
results.creator_credit: Winifred Holmes, Oswald Skilbeck and Southalls Ltd
results.brief_description: An account of the processes of human gestation from fertilization to the birth of a child. The film answers many question which arise in the mind of a fourteen-year-old child. Shows the visits of the mother to a baby clinic; explains how the human egg is fertilized; how menstruation ceases; the creation of the embryo, its growth to a nine-month baby, and its ultimate delivery.

results.title: 800 miles of winter (TEFC)
results.brief_description: From the discovery of oil at Prudhoe Bay in 1968 to the loading of the first tankers at Valdez in 1977, this is the story of one of the most difficult and costly construction projects ever attempted. Almost 800 miles of big pipe was laid across three major mountain ranges and Arctic perma-frost, to reach an ice free port in south east Alaska. (Award: Golden Eagle, USA)

results.title: 2am feeding
results.brief_description: This film is a realistic look at parenting during the first few months after birth. It touches on a wide range of parental concerns, such as nursing, crying and colic, fatigue, mother’s recovery, sexuality, fathering, single parenthood, and returning to work. The film is straight forward, presenting a diverse group of new parents who relate their experiences with warmth and humour. Narrated by Robbie Engelmann.
